title: The 30% Rent Rule: Is It Still Useful Today?
summary: For many years, people have been told to spend no more than 30% of their money on rent when finding a home. This is called the 30% rule. But today, with high housing costs, experts are asking if this rule still works. A study shows that nearly two-thirds of renters struggle to afford rent. Some experts say the rule is helpful for most people, but it has limits. For very poor or very rich people, the rule might not make sense. The rule started long ago to help families budget, and it was used in government programs. Now, in expensive cities, it can be hard to follow this rule. Experts suggest that renters might need other strategies to manage their money better.

background_read: The 30% rule is an old piece of advice that says people should not spend more than 30% of their income on rent. It was created to help families budget their money, especially during tough times like the Great Depression. Over time, the government used this rule in housing programs to decide how much help people needed. Today, with rents going up in many places, some people find it hard to stick to this rule. Experts study this to see if it still helps people afford homes without struggling to pay for other things like food or bills. Understanding this rule can help us think about how to make smart choices with our money.
Article_Structure: WHO: Experts like Daryl Fairweather and Chris Herbert, and renters.
WHAT: The 30% rule for rent spending and if it still works today.
WHERE: In cities across the U.S., like New York and San Francisco.
WHY: To help people understand if old financial advice is still useful with high housing costs.

perspectives.description: Some experts think the 30% rule is still helpful for most people as a simple guideline to manage money.
Other experts point out that the rule doesn't work well for very poor or very rich people, and in expensive cities, it might be unrealistic.
